awd_titl_txt: A low-cost float for distributed, Lagrangian observations of the biological carbon pump
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop ocean observing floats using new technologies for tracking and imaging the transport of individual particles to the deep ocean and contribute to our understanding of the biological carbon pump (BCP). Tracking what happens to carbon in our oceans is critical for understanding the world's climate. If successful, the floats will collect data that could provide new insights with respect to our understanding of the Biological Carbon Pump (BCP) and global carbon cycling. The project will also support graduate student participation.

The transport of organic carbon from the ocean's surface to its abyssal depths plays a central role in regulating atmospheric carbon, and thus the climate. Understanding the "Biological Carbon Pump", is thus crucial to predicting the evolution of the world's climate. However, due to the complexity of this process and the limitations of available observations (largely from bulk geochemical analyses of the contents of particle-intercepting traps), predictions of oceanic carbon sequestration remain extremely uncertain. What we need now are autonomous tools which are both Lagrangian, essential for accurately quantifying respiration, sinking rates, and fluxes, and widely deployable (low cost), essential for reducing spatial and temporal aliasing, and for ensuring statistical significance. The proposed float technology will merge recent technological developments in environmental tag technology and low-cost imaging into a modular, low-cost platform that will result in the next generation of observing platforms and have a large impact on the state of our understanding of important carbon pathways. The goal is to make possible dense distributions of Lagrangian platforms that can directly observe the transport and transformation of individual particles that drive the BCP.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The transport of organic carbon from the ocean’s surface to its depths, known as the biological carbon pump (BCP), is a key process in the global carbon cycle, affecting how much atmospheric carbon is stored by the ocean, and for how long. The efficiency of the BCP depends on the rate of bacterial remineralization and the sinking speed of organic particles. Historically, the primary method for studying this process was with particle-intercepting traps (PITs) which are limited in spatial coverage and duration due to their high cost and logistical constraints.

This project enabled the development of the a miniature, autonomous float called MINION which was designed to overcome the limitations of PITs by providing broader, more distributed measurements of carbon export in a small housing, with low materials and labor costs and open-source design and software. The floats are passively-ballasted, and designed to closely follow water movement, allowing sinking particles to accumulate on an upward-facing camera. The image sequence can be analyzed to provide a proxy for sinking particulate flux. The system also includes sensors like temperature, pressure, and oxygen, which can enable calculation of mesopelagic respiration rates. The design of the MINION control system emphasizes low cost, low power consumption for long-term data collection, ease of use, and flexibility to allow for future sensor additions. The project supported two engineering student MSc theses and four undergraduate internships. Over the course of the project, a field-ready prototype was developed and successfully deployed to depths ranging from 50 to 1500 ft sub-surface in a range of marine environments spanning the sub-tropical Pacific to the subpolar North Atlantic Ocean.
